title: 106_s2463
content:
The Act titled "National Death Penalty Moratorium Act of 2000" establishes a moratorium on the death penalty. Congress finds that death sentences are disproportionately imposed on the poor and certain racial and ethnic groups, with the majority of individuals facing capital charges unable to afford their own attorney. Additionally, no state has met the standards set by the American Bar Association for providing counsel to indigent prisoners. Since 1976, African-Americans have been disproportionately represented in executions, death row populations, and victims of the death penalty, despite making up only 13% of the population. In death penalty cases, 84% of victims are white, even though they only make up 50% of murder victims. (A) In death penalty cases, 84% of victims are white. 
(B) A 1994 study found that 89% of defendants chosen for capital prosecution under the Anti-Drug Abuse Act of 1988 were African-American or Hispanic American. 
(C) A 1990 report by the General Accounting Office highlighted racial disparities in charging, sentencing, and imposition of the death penalty. The Supreme Court has restricted death row prisoners' rights to appeal convictions and sentences in Federal courts, increasing the risk of imprisoning and executing innocent individuals. New legislation in 1996 further limited these appeals. In 1996, new legislation limited Federal court review of death penalty appeals and reduced public funding for legal aid services for death row prisoners, even when they present compelling evidence of innocence. The Federal and State death penalty is currently on hold until Congress reviews the final findings and recommendations of the National Commission on the Death Penalty. This moratorium will continue until legislation is enacted based on the Commission's guidelines and procedures. The National Commission on the Death Penalty is established with 15 members appointed by the President in consultation with relevant officials. Members include Federal or State prosecutors and experienced attorneys. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members appointed by the President, including prosecutors, defense attorneys, judges, law enforcement officials, and individuals with expertise in relevant matters. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members appointed by the President, including individuals with knowledge or expertise in relevant matters from various sectors such as government, academia, nonprofit organizations, industry, and other interested individuals. The President appoints members with balanced viewpoints to the maximum extent. The National Commission on the Death Penalty consists of 15 members appointed by the President, ensuring a balance of viewpoints regarding the use of the death penalty. The initial appointments must be made within 30 days of the Act's enactment. Members serve for a specified period and vacancies are filled as needed. The Commission shall be appointed for life and vacancies will be filled promptly. The first meeting must be held within 30 days of all initial members being appointed. Meetings will be called by the Chairperson and a majority of members constitute a quorum for conducting business. The Commission shall appoint a Chairperson, who will be designated by the President. A majority of members will constitute a quorum for conducting business, and the Commission will adopt rules and procedures to govern its proceedings. SEC. 202. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is required to conduct a comprehensive study on the administration of the death penalty to ensure it aligns with constitutional principles of fairness, justice, equality, and due process. This study will include examining racial disparities and disproportionality in capital charging, prosecuting, and sentencing decisions. The Commission will study racial disparities and disproportionality in capital charging, prosecuting, and sentencing decisions, including adequacy of representation for capital defendants. The Commission will study racial disparities and disproportionality in capital cases, including competency of counsel, wrongful convictions, federal death penalty in states without it, and the adequacy of courts in reviewing constitutional claims. The Commission will study racial disparities and disproportionality in capital cases, including competency of counsel, wrongful convictions, federal death penalty in states without it, and the adequacy of courts in reviewing constitutional claims. Additionally, the Commission will address issues such as whether mentally retarded persons and individuals under 18 at the time of their offenses should be sentenced to death, and procedures to ensure access to forensic evidence and DNA testing for persons sentenced to death. The Commission will establish guidelines and procedures for the administration of the death penalty, ensuring fairness and impartiality in accordance with the Constitution. This includes access to forensic evidence and DNA testing to potentially uncover new evidence of innocence. The guidelines and procedures for the administration of the death penalty aim to ensure fair and impartial treatment, minimize the risk of executing innocent individuals, and prevent racial discrimination in the process. A report is required within one year of implementation. The guidelines for administering the death penalty aim to prevent racial discrimination. A preliminary report is due within one year, and a final report within two years of enactment. The Commission's report to the President, Attorney General, and Congress will include detailed findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions based on guidelines to prevent racial discrimination in administering the death penalty. SEC. 203. POWERS OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission can obtain information from Federal and State agencies, use postal services, accept gifts, and conduct hearings as necessary. The Commission has the authority to accept gifts, conduct hearings, and subpoena witnesses and documents for the purpose of carrying out its provisions. The Commission has the authority to subpoena records, correspondence, memoranda, papers, documents, tapes, and materials as deemed necessary. Subpoenas are issued by the Chairperson and enforced by the district court in case of non-compliance. The district court can issue an order to compel a person to testify or produce evidence in response to a subpoena. Failure to comply may result in contempt charges. Additionally, a court within the jurisdiction where a person in custody is held can also compel their testimony. The district court can issue a writ of habeas corpus ad testificandum to compel a person in custody to testify before the Commission. Witness allowances and fees follow the provisions of title 28, United States Code. Witnesses requested or subpoenaed to appear at Commission hearings will be subject to the provisions of title 28, United States Code. Per diem and mileage allowances for witnesses will be paid from Commission funds. SEC. 204. COMMISSION PERSONNEL MATTERS. Members of the Commission serve without compensation but are allowed travel expenses. The Chairperson can appoint an executive director and staff without following civil service laws. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint and terminate an executive director and additional personnel without following civil service laws. The executive director's compensation can be determined by the Chairperson without adhering to specific regulations. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint an executive director and personnel with pay rates not exceeding level V of the Executive Schedule. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Chairperson can also procure temporary and intermittent services. The Chairperson of the Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 205. TERMINATION OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission will end 90 days after submitting its report under section 202. SEC. 206. FUNDING. The Commission can spend up to $850,000 to carry out its duties, with funds provided by the Department of Justice.
